lua

namespace lua
Summary
Enumerations
Error_HandlerSpecifies how errors should be handled in State.do_string and State.do_file.

Enumerations

Error_Handler

Specifies how errors should be handled in State.do_string and State.do_file.  ERROR_NONE makes it not push the traceback.  ERROR_TRACEBACK does.  ERROR_EXIT throws a Lua error without traceback.  ERROR_EXIT_TRACEBACK throws a Lua error with traceback.

State

struct State

The state class.  It holds the raw Lua state, the global and registry tables, the traceback and are the thing you interface with in exposed functions.

Functions

State

State(): p_state(luaL_newstate()), p_owner(true)

Initializes a state.  As this has to create a new Lua raw state, it marks itself as owner of the raw state.

State

State(const State &s): p_state(s.p_state), p_owner(false)

Initializes a state from existing Lua state, so it’s not its owner.

State

State(lua_State *L): p_state(L), p_owner(false)

Initializes a state from existing raw Lua state, so it’s not its owner.

State

~State()

This clears up traceback, registry and global tables and if it’s also the owner of the raw state, deinitializes the raw state.

state

lua_State *state() const

Returns the raw Lua state held by this State.

state

Retrieves a Lua state from a raw pointer.

set_panic_handler

void set_panic_handler(void (*fun)(const State&, const char*))

Sets a panic handler.  It’s a function that takes two arguments, the first one being const reference to State, the second one being the error message.  It’s called everytime something throws an error.

error

int error(const char *fmt,
 ...)

Manually throws an error.

open_libs

void open_libs()

Opens all core Lua libraries.  Use open_* to open the specific ones or just use raw Lua functions.

open_base

void open_base()

void open_table()

open_io

void open_io()

open_os

void open_os()

void open_string()

open_math

void open_math()

open_debug

void open_debug()

This one besides opening the library also initializes the traceback function in the state (which is a reference to debug.traceback)

open_package

void open_package()

globals

const Table& globals() const

Returns a const reference to the global table belonging to the current state.

registry

const Table& registry() const

Returns a const reference to the registry table belonging to the current state.

load_string

types::Tuple<int, const char*, Function> load_string(const char *code) const

Compiles Lua code contained in the given string.  Returns a tuple of 3 values of types int (error code, zero on success, otherwise see lua_load), const char* (error message, NULL on success) and Function (on success, the runnable compiled function).

load_string

types::Tuple<int, const char*, Function> load_string(
   const types::String &code
) const

load_file

types::Tuple<int, const char*, Function> load_file(const char *path) const

Compiles Lua code contained in a file in the given path.  Behaves and returns the same as load_string.

load_file

types::Tuple<int, const char*, Function> load_file(
   const types::String &path
) const

do_string

types::Tuple<int, const char*> do_string(
   const char *code,  
   Error_Handler handler =  ERROR_NONE
) const

Runs Lua code contained in the given string.  See also lua.Error_Handler.  This function returns a tuple of two values, an integer (being 0 on success, and one of error codes returned by luaL_loadstring or lua_pcall on failure) and a const char*, being NULL on success and error message on failure.

do_string

types::Tuple<int, const char*> do_string(
   const types::String &code,  
   Error_Handler handler =  ERROR_NONE
) const

do_file

types::Tuple<int, const char*> do_file(const char *path,  
Error_Handler handler =  ERROR_NONE) const

See do_string.  This behaves and returns the same, but instead of running a piece of code, it runs a file containing Lua code.

do_file

types::Tuple<int, const char*> do_file(const types::String &path,  
Error_Handler handler =  ERROR_NONE) const

do_string

template<typename... T> types::Tuple<int, const char*> do_string(
   const char *code,  
   types::Tuple<T...> &retvals,  
   Error_Handler handler =  ERROR_NONE
) const

Runs Lua code contained in the string, saving the return values into a tuple given by “retvals”.  Otherwise behaves the same as do_string above.

do_string

template<typename... T> types::Tuple<int, const char*> do_string(
   const types::String &code,  
   types::Tuple<T...> &retvals,  
   Error_Handler handler =  ERROR_NONE
) const

do_file

template<typename... T> types::Tuple<int, const char*> do_file(
   const char *path,  
   types::Tuple<T...> &retvals,  
   Error_Handler handler =  ERROR_NONE
) const

Runs Lua code contained in the file, saving the return values into a tuple given by “retvals”.  Otherwise behaves the same as do_file above.

do_file

template<typename... T> types::Tuple<int, const char*> do_file(
   const types::String &path,  
   types::Tuple<T...> &retvals,  
   Error_Handler handler =  ERROR_NONE
) const

new_table

Table new_table(size_t narr =  0,
size_t nrec =  0) const

Creates a new Lua table and returns it.  The arguments are optional.  They specify the number of pre-initialized array slots and the number of pre-initialized non-array slots.

register_module

void register_module(const char *name,
const Table &t)

Registers a Lua module, given a name and a table with functions.  If such module is not yet registered, the table will basically become the module, including possible metatable.

If such module is already registered, the table will be appended to it without overriding metatable.

If such global variable already exists and it’s not a module, it’ll fail with name clash error.

register_module

void register_module(const types::String &name,
const Table &t)

See above.

wrap

template<typename T = Object, typename U> T wrap(const U &value) const

Wraps any given value of type U supported by stack.push_value in a container of type T (by default Object).  Useful for i.e. wrapping real C++ values in the Dynamic container and then doing Lua actions on them.

get

template<typename T = Object, typename... U> T get(const U&... args) const

Gets something from the global table.  This function has the same behavior as Table.get (it’s done on the global table).

set

template<typename T, typename U> void set(const T &key,
const U &value) const

Gives a global variable of the given name the given value.  Performs on the global table.

[]

template<typename T> Table_Item<T> operator[](const T &key) const

This operator is for both getting and setting.  It returns Table_Item, which you can further convert or assign.  The returned table item belongs to the global table.

pop_stack

template<typename T> types::Vector<T> pop_stack(int n =  -1) const

See stack.pop_stack.

get_stack

template<typename T> types::Vector<T> get_stack(int n =  -1) const

See stack.get_stack.

pop_value

template<typename T> T pop_value() const

See stack.pop_value.

push_value

template<typename T> void push_value(const T &arg) const

See stack.push_value.

struct Object
This is an object, a container holding a reference to any Lua type.

See stack.pop_stack.
template<typename T> inline types::Vector<T> pop_stack(lua_State *L,
int n)
Calls get_stack, pops out required amount of items from the stack and returns the vector.
template<typename T> types::Vector<T> get_stack(int n =  -1) const
See stack.get_stack.
template<typename T> inline types::Vector<T> get_stack(lua_State *L,
int n)
Gets contents of the whole stack and returns them in a Vector.
template<typename T> T pop_value() const
See stack.pop_value.
template<typename T> inline T pop_value(lua_State *L)
Gets a value from the stack using get_value and pops it out.
template<typename T> void push_value(const T &arg) const
See stack.push_value.
Specifies how errors should be handled in State.do_string and State.do_file.
struct Dynamic: Function
This is a “Dynamic”, a generic object that can behave as a value, a bit like table, function, etc.
template<typename T = Object, typename... U> T get(const U&... args) const
Gets an element of this table or of a contained table, depending on the amount of arguments.
template<typename T> struct Table_Item
Represents a table element.
